questions.question_text: Do we need to fix it within the next 3 months?
questions.description: This question assesses the time criticality of addressing the problem. Consider whether the issue requires a functional solution within the next three months (e.g. to avoid operational disruption, compliance issues, or missed opportunities), or whether it can be addressed as part of a longer-term improvement initiative

questions.question_text: What is the earliest realistic timeframe to deliver usable value?
questions.description: This question assesses the organisation’s realistic expectation for when a first usable version of the solution can deliver value.

questions.question_text: Is this a business process improvement or mission supporting?
questions.description: This question distinguishes whether the problem primarily concerns improving internal operations and workflows or directly supporting the mission.

questions.question_text: Is there a clear beneficiary or end user?
questions.description: This question assesses whether there is a clearly identifiable group or role that will use the solution and benefit from it.

questions.question_text: How willing is your org to spend money on a tech solution?
questions.description: Assesses whether the organisation is willing and able to allocate budget to a technical solution.

questions.question_text: Does your org already have an AI policy?
questions.description: This question assesses whether there are established organisational policies or guidelines governing the use of AI. Such policies provide a common framework for decision-making regarding ethics, risk, and procurement.

questions.question_text: Attitude within org toward AI?
questions.description: Assesses the overall organisational attitude toward AI and advanced technologies.

questions.question_text: Champions/Ambassador: Can you identify an influential person who has the flexibility to support efforts/experiments?
questions.description: Assesses whether there is at least one person with the mandate, credibility, and decision-making power to actively support and drive experimentation or implementation.

questions.question_text: What are your donors' attitude toward AI?
questions.description: Assesses how key donors or funders are likely to perceive investments in AI. Consider past interactions and funding conditions to estimate support or reputational risk.

questions.question_text: Is the system addressing a missing critical area?
questions.description: Determines if the problem being addressed is central to the organization's primary goals.

questions.question_text: Is there a manual redundancy/fallback system in place?
questions.description: Assesses if a non-technical process exists that can be used if the system is unavailable or produces unreliable results.

questions.question_text: Would a mistake be life-threatening?
questions.description: Assesses whether failure or incorrect behavior could directly lead to loss of life. Consider worst-case scenarios.

questions.question_text: Would a mistake of the system affect your material/assets?
questions.description: Assesses whether system failure would place the organization’s physical or core mission-related assets at risk.

questions.question_text: Would a mistake of the system affect your staff?
questions.description: Consider physical, psychological, legal, or workload-related impacts on staff due to errors or system failure.

questions.question_text: Would a mistake of the system affect customers/beneficiaries/donors?
questions.description: Assesses negative impacts such as reduced service quality, loss of trust, or unmet expectations for external stakeholders.

questions.question_text: Would a mistake affect of your system your mission/mandate?
questions.description: Assesses whether system failure could undermine a specific operation or project that contributes to the organization's mission.

questions.question_text: Would a mistake of the system affect your reputation?
questions.description: Assesses whether errors or failure could lead to reputational damage or loss of trust among external stakeholders and the public.

questions.question_text: Do you already have the data the system will use?
questions.description: Assesses whether the datasets required by the system are already available in a machine-readable format.

questions.question_text: Do you know how to collect data in future for the system if necessary?
questions.description: This question assesses whether there is a clear and feasible plan to obtain any additional data required by the system in the future. Consider internal processes, partnerships, sensors, surveys, or data purchases.

questions.question_text: What data formats will be used in the system?
questions.description: Identifies the data formats that the system will actively process, analyse, or manipulate.

questions.question_text: What is the expected quantity of data used in your system?
questions.description: This question assesses the scale of data the system is expected to process, analyse, or store. Larger volumes often lead to higher computational cost and infrastructure needs.

questions.question_text: What frequency of use do you foresee for the system?
questions.description: Assesses how often the system is expected to be actively used. Systems used more frequently place higher demands on reliability and maintenance.

questions.question_text: Are you able to define the scope of the project very precisely?
questions.description: A well-defined scope reduces uncertainty and implementation risk. Assesses if objectives and success criteria are unlikely to change.

questions.question_text: Can you list in detail the exact tasks the system will fulfil?
questions.description: Being able to list concrete tasks helps translate needs into requirements and reduces ambiguity during implementation.

questions.question_text: Can you clearly distinguish between core functionality and nice-to-have features?
questions.description: Assesses whether the organisation has a clear understanding of the system’s core functions.

questions.question_text: If you would only implement core functionality to have a minimal viable product?
questions.description: Assesses whether delivering only core functions would already provide meaningful value.

questions.question_text: Will the project be outward-facing? (e.g. a digital service for partners or costumers)
questions.description: Outward-facing systems typically require higher standards for reliability, security, and governance.

questions.question_text: Where will the system primarily be used?
questions.description: Assesses the physical and organisational context in which the system will be used.

questions.question_text: Will the system need to function with limited or no internet connectivity?
questions.description: Connectivity constraints have major implications for system architecture, data synchronisation, complexity, and maintenance.

questions.question_text: Do you have an established way to store data to make it centrally accessible?
questions.description: Central data storage is a prerequisite for collaboration, automation, version control, security, and long-term sustainability.

questions.question_text: Do you have IT support already?
questions.description: Assesses whether the organisation has a basic, established IT contact, role, or unit responsible for IT systems and infrastructure.

questions.question_text: Is your IT support capable of running and maintaining the system?
questions.description: Assesses whether existing IT support has the practical capacity and skills for routine operation, updates, and security.

questions.question_text: Does the project require building an entirely new system or tool?
questions.description: Assesses user adoption and change management. Extending familiar tools often simplifies the transition for users.

questions.question_text: Will the system require system integration in the existing tech infrastructure?
questions.description: Focuses on technical dependencies such as data exchange or shared authentication with existing systems.
